questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like the curare group of muscle relaxants?

options.label: B
options.text: Persistent Depolarization at the Ach Receptors

options.label: C
options.text: Competitively Blocking the binding of ACh to its Receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibiting the Calcium Channel on the Neuronal Membrane

questions.correct_answer: C. Competitively Blocking the binding of ACh to its Receptors
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Competitively Blocking the binding of ACh to its Receptors

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Persistent Depolarization at Neuromuscular Junction : is not the correct mechanism . Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers do not cause persistent depolarization ; instead, they block the depolarization initiated by acetylcholine .
  • • Option A.
  • • Persistent Depolarization at Neuromuscular Junction
  • • not the correct mechanism
  • • do not
  • • persistent depolarization
  • • block
  • • depolarization initiated by acetylcholine
  • • Option B. Persistent Depolarization at the ACh Receptors : is not accurate . These drugs do not cause persistent depolarization ; they prevent depolarization by inhibiting ACh binding.
  • • Option B.
  • • Persistent Depolarization at the ACh Receptors
  • • not accurate
  • • do not cause persistent depolarization
  • • prevent depolarization
  • • Option D . Inhibiting the Calcium Channel on the Neuronal Membrane : is not the mechanism of action for non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers . These drugs do not directly affect calcium channels .
  • • Option D
  • • Inhibiting the Calcium Channel on the Neuronal Membrane
  • • not
  • • mechanism of action
  • • non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers
  • • do not directly
  • • affect calcium channels
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers competitively block the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors , leading to muscle relaxation and paralysis , and are essential in anesthesia and critical care for various medical procedures .
  • • competitively block
  • • binding
  • • acetylcholine
  • • receptors
  • • leading
  • • muscle relaxation
  • • paralysis
  • • essential
  • • anesthesia
  • • critical care
  • • medical procedures
  • • Ref : Millers anesthesia 8th edition page 959-965
  • • Ref : Millers anesthesia 8th edition page 959-965

questions.text: Identify the drug which does not belong to the curare group of muscle relaxants?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Succinylcholine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Pancuronium : Pancuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent and belongs to the curare group of muscle relaxants . It acts by competitively blocking the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors at the neuromuscular junction .
  • • Option A
  • • Pancuronium
  • • non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent
  • • belongs
  • • curare group
  • • muscle relaxants
  • • competitively blocking
  • • binding
  • • acetylcholine to its receptors
  • • neuromuscular junction
  • • Option B . D-Tubocurarine : D-Tubocurarine is the prototypical non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent and is a classic member of the curare group . It exerts its effects by blocking nicotinic acetylcholine receptors .
  • • Option B
  • • D-Tubocurarine
  • • prototypical non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent
  • • classic member
  • • curare group
  • • exerts
  • • blocking nicotinic acetylcholine receptors
  • • Option D . Vecuronium : Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent and is part of the curare group . It acts as a competitive antagonist at the neuromuscular junction .
  • • Option D
  • • Vecuronium
  • • non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent
  • • curare group
  • • competitive antagonist
  • • neuromuscular junction
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Suxamethonium or succinyl choline is a depolarizing muscle relaxant . It does not belong to the curare group.
  • • depolarizing muscle relaxant
  • • Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 5 th edition pg 210
  • • Ref :
  • • Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 5 th edition pg 210

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is posted for emergency exploratory laparotomy; the anaesthetist wants to perform rapid sequence intubation. What would be the muscle relaxant of choice for rapid sequence intubation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Succinylcholine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Muscle relaxant of choice for rapid sequence intubation is Succinylcholine is due to:
  • • Muscle relaxant
  • • choice
  • • rapid sequence intubation
  • • Rapid onset of action Shortest acting muscle relaxant
  • • Rapid onset of action
  • • Rapid onset
  • • action
  • • Shortest acting muscle relaxant
  • • Shortest acting muscle relaxant
  • • In case of contraindication to succinylcholine – drug of choice for RSI – Rocuronium
  • • In case of contraindication to succinylcholine – drug of choice for RSI – Rocuronium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The muscle relaxant of choice for rapid sequence intubation is Succinylcholine
  • ➤ The muscle relaxant of choice for rapid sequence intubation is Succinylcholine
  • ➤ Ref : Millers Anesthesia 8th ed pg 1020

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is posted for emergency exploratory laparotomy; the anaesthetist wants to perform rapid sequence intubation. Succinylcholine can be used in all of the following patients except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Burns Patient : Burns can lead to an increased release of potassium from damaged cells , potentially causing Hyperkalemia . Succinylcholine, a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker , can further elevate potassium levels and should be avoided in burn patients to prevent life-threatening Hyperkalemia .
  • • Option A
  • • Burns Patient
  • • lead
  • • increased release
  • • potassium
  • • damaged cells
  • • potentially causing Hyperkalemia
  • • depolarizing neuromuscular blocker
  • • elevate potassium levels
  • • avoided
  • • burn patients
  • • prevent life-threatening Hyperkalemia
  • • Option B . Spinal Cord Injury : Patients with spinal cord injuries may have altered regulation of potassium due to impaired neural control . Succinylcholine administration can lead to uncontrolled potassium release and severe Hyperkalemia in these patients.
  • • Option B
  • • Spinal Cord Injury
  • • may
  • • altered regulation of potassium
  • • impaired neural control
  • • uncontrolled potassium release
  • • severe Hyperkalemia
  • • Option C . Guillain-Barre Syndrome : Guillain-Barre syndrome is a neurological disorder that can affect the peripheral nervous system . Patients with this condition may already have altered neuromuscular transmission , and succinylcholine can exacerbate the risk of Hyperkalemia .
  • • Option C
  • • Guillain-Barre Syndrome
  • • neurological disorder
  • • affect
  • • peripheral nervous system
  • • already
  • • altered neuromuscular transmission
  • • succinylcholine
  • • exacerbate
  • • risk of Hyperkalemia
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Succinylcholine in certain conditions can cause life-threatening Hyperkalemia . These conditions are:
  • • cause life-threatening Hyperkalemia
  • • Burns Spinal cord injury Old stroke Tetanus Prolonged immobilization Myopathies Guillain-Barre syndrome Malignant hyperthermia history
  • • Burns
  • • Spinal cord injury
  • • Old stroke
  • • Tetanus
  • • Prolonged immobilization
  • • Myopathies
  • • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • • Malignant hyperthermia history
  • • Note - Pre-existing Hyperkalemia conditions like A) Chronic Renal Failure B) Head Injury C) Advanced liver failure/sepsis due to decreases concentration of Pseudocholine-esterase D) Duchene Muscle dystrophy/Dystrophia myotonica E) Avoid in the new-born (extra-junctional receptors which increase the K+ level).
  • • Note - Pre-existing Hyperkalemia
  • • Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 5 th edition pg 210
  • • Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 5 th edition pg 210

questions.text: The enzyme that degrades succinylcholine is called as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Butyrylcholinesterase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Butyrylcholinesterase/ Pseudocholinesterase is the enzyme which degrades succinyl choline . It is synthesized in the liver and found in the plasma .
  • • Butyrylcholinesterase/ Pseudocholinesterase
  • • enzyme
  • • degrades succinyl choline
  • • synthesized
  • • liver
  • • found in the plasma
  • • Enzyme activity is reduced in:
  • • Liver disease Pregnancy Malnutrition Old age Use of drugs like - oral contraceptives, monoamine oxidase inhibitors
  • • Liver disease
  • • Pregnancy
  • • Malnutrition
  • • Old age
  • • Use of drugs like - oral contraceptives, monoamine oxidase inhibitors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Butyrylcholinesterase/ Pseudocholinesterase is the enzyme that degrades succinyl choline.
  • ➤ Butyrylcholinesterase/ Pseudocholinesterase is the enzyme that degrades succinyl choline.
  • ➤ Ref : Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 961
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 961

questions.text: Normal Dibucaine number is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 80

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Dibucaine number is a laboratory test used to assess the function of the enzyme pseudocholinesterase (also known as butyrylcholinesterase ) in the blood .
  • • Dibucaine number
  • • laboratory test
  • • assess the function
  • • enzyme pseudocholinesterase
  • • butyrylcholinesterase
  • • blood
  • • Pseudocholinesterase is an enzyme responsible for breaking down certain drugs , including the muscle relaxant succinylcholine (also known as suxamethonium ).
  • • enzyme responsible for breaking down certain drugs
  • • muscle relaxant succinylcholine
  • • suxamethonium
  • • Normal Dibucaine Number : In individuals with normal pseudocholinesterase activity , the Dibucaine number is typically around 80 . This means that Dibucaine, a specific local anesthetic , can inhibit 80% of the enzyme's activity . In other words, Dibucaine has a moderate effect on slowing down the breakdown of certain drugs by pseudocholinesterase in individuals with a Dibucaine number of 80 . Abnormal Dibucaine Number : Some individuals may have genetic variations that lead to abnormal pseudocholinesterase function . For example, individuals who are homozygous for an atypical form of pseudocholinesterase may have a Dibucaine number as low as 20 . In such cases, Dibucaine has a much stronger inhibitory effect on the enzyme's activity . Clinical Significance : The Dibucaine number is clinically relevant when using drugs like succinylcholine, a muscle relaxant often used during anesthesia . Pseudocholinesterase plays a crucial role in rapidly breaking down succinylcholine , allowing the muscles to regain their function after its use. If a patient has an abnormal Dibucaine number (e.g., 20), it indicates reduced pseudocholinesterase activity . As a result, the patient may experience delayed recovery from muscle relaxation induced by succinylcholine .
  • • Normal Dibucaine Number : In individuals with normal pseudocholinesterase activity , the Dibucaine number is typically around 80 . This means that Dibucaine, a specific local anesthetic , can inhibit 80% of the enzyme's activity . In other words, Dibucaine has a moderate effect on slowing down the breakdown of certain drugs by pseudocholinesterase in individuals with a Dibucaine number of 80 .
  • • Normal Dibucaine Number
  • • normal pseudocholinesterase activity
  • • typically around 80
  • • specific local anesthetic
  • • inhibit 80% of the enzyme's activity
  • • moderate effect
  • • slowing down
  • • breakdown
  • • pseudocholinesterase
  • • individuals
  • • Dibucaine number of 80
  • • Abnormal Dibucaine Number : Some individuals may have genetic variations that lead to abnormal pseudocholinesterase function . For example, individuals who are homozygous for an atypical form of pseudocholinesterase may have a Dibucaine number as low as 20 . In such cases, Dibucaine has a much stronger inhibitory effect on the enzyme's activity .
  • • Abnormal Dibucaine Number
  • • genetic variations
  • • lead
  • • abnormal pseudocholinesterase function
  • • individuals
  • • homozygous
  • • atypical form
  • • pseudocholinesterase
  • • Dibucaine number as low as 20
  • • much stronger inhibitory effect
  • • enzyme's activity
  • • Clinical Significance : The Dibucaine number is clinically relevant when using drugs like succinylcholine, a muscle relaxant often used during anesthesia . Pseudocholinesterase plays a crucial role in rapidly breaking down succinylcholine , allowing the muscles to regain their function after its use. If a patient has an abnormal Dibucaine number (e.g., 20), it indicates reduced pseudocholinesterase activity . As a result, the patient may experience delayed recovery from muscle relaxation induced by succinylcholine .
  • • Clinical Significance
  • • clinically relevant
  • • muscle relaxant
  • • during anesthesia
  • • crucial role
  • • rapidly breaking down succinylcholine
  • • allowing the muscles
  • • regain their function
  • • abnormal Dibucaine number
  • • indicates reduced pseudocholinesterase activity
  • • experience delayed recovery
  • • muscle relaxation induced by succinylcholine
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • The Dibucaine number is a measure of pseudocholinesterase function , and a normal value is around 80 . Abnormal values, particularly a low Dibucaine number , can have clinical implications , especially when using drugs like succinylcholine during surgery.
  • • measure of pseudocholinesterase function
  • • normal value is around 80
  • • low Dibucaine number
  • • clinical implications

questions.text: Succinylcholine was first synthesized by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Bovet

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . John S. Lundy : He was one of the first to use the term " Balanced Anesthesia " and contributed to the widespread use of local and regional anesthesia techniques .
  • • Option A
  • • John S. Lundy
  • • one of the first to use the term
  • • Balanced Anesthesia
  • • contributed
  • • widespread use of local and regional anesthesia techniques
  • • Option B . WTG Morton : William Thomas Green Morton was a dentist and a prominent figure in the history of anesthesia. He is best known for his successful public demonstration of the use of ether as a surgical anesthetic in 1846 , which revolutionized surgical practice by allowing patients to undergo procedures without pain .
  • • Option B
  • • WTG Morton
  • • William Thomas Green Morton
  • • dentist
  • • prominent figure
  • • best known
  • • successful public demonstration
  • • use of ether
  • • surgical anesthetic
  • • 1846
  • • revolutionized surgical practice
  • • allowing patients
  • • undergo procedures
  • • without pain
  • • Option D . John Snow : John Snow is often called the father of modern epidemiology . He's most famous for his work in tracing the source of a cholera outbreak in London in 1854 , which he linked to a contaminated water pump . His work laid the foundations for modern epidemiology and public health . Snow also made significant contributions to anesthesiology and is known for his work on ether and chloroform .
  • • Option D
  • • John Snow
  • • called the father of modern epidemiology
  • • most famous
  • • work in tracing
  • • source of a cholera outbreak in London in 1854
  • • linked to a contaminated water pump
  • • laid the foundations
  • • modern epidemiology and public health
  • • significant contributions
  • • anesthesiology
  • • work on ether and chloroform

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Succinylcholine was first synthesized by Bovet
  • ➤ Succinylcholine was first synthesized by Bovet
  • ➤ Ref : Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 1020
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 1020

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of succinylcholine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Sinus Tachycardia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Hyperkalemia : Succinylcholine can cause an increase in serum potassium levels , which is especially risky in patients with pre-existing hyperkalemia or those with risk factors for increased potassium release , such as burn or crush injuries, neuromuscular diseases , or prolonged immobilization .
  • • Option B
  • • Hyperkalemia
  • • increase
  • • serum potassium levels
  • • especially risky
  • • pre-existing hyperkalemia
  • • risk factors
  • • increased potassium release
  • • neuromuscular diseases
  • • prolonged immobilization
  • • Option C . Myalgia : Muscle pain , or myalgia, is a common side effect following the administration of succinylcholine due to muscle fasciculations that occur before muscle relaxation . It is often experienced as generalized muscle soreness after recovery from anesthesia .
  • • Option C
  • • Myalgia
  • • Muscle pain
  • • common side effect
  • • succinylcholine
  • • muscle fasciculations
  • • before muscle relaxation
  • • often experienced
  • • generalized muscle soreness
  • • recovery from anesthesia
  • • Option D . Masseter Spasm : This is a known side effect of succinylcholine and is considered an early sign of malignant hyperthermia , a rare but life-threatening reaction to certain drugs used for anesthesia .
  • • Option D
  • • Masseter Spasm
  • • known side effect
  • • succinylcholine
  • • early sign of malignant hyperthermia
  • • rare
  • • life-threatening reaction
  • • drugs used for anesthesia
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Cardiovascular side effects of succinylcholine:
  • • Cardiovascular side effects of succinylcholine:
  • • Sinus Bradycardia Junctional Rhythm Ventricular Dysrhythmias
  • • Sinus Bradycardia
  • • Junctional Rhythm
  • • Ventricular Dysrhythmias
  • • Ref : Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 962-964
  • • Ref :
  • • Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 962-964

questions.text: Use of succinylcholine increases plasma K+ level by ------ mEq/L?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 0.5 mEq/L

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Succinylcholine is known to cause an elevation in plasma potassium levels due the following mechanism of action .
  • • Succinylcholine
  • • elevation in plasma potassium levels
  • • mechanism of action
  • • When succinylcholine is administered , it binds to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction , leading to depolarization of the muscle cell membrane . This depolarization causes the muscle cells to release potassium into the bloodstream .
  • • administered
  • • binds to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors
  • • neuromuscular junction
  • • depolarization of the muscle cell membrane
  • • depolarization
  • • muscle cells
  • • release potassium
  • • bloodstream
  • • The use of succinylcholine typically increases plasma potassium levels by about 0.5 mEq/L . This increase is usually clinically insignificant in healthy patients but can be dangerous in patients with higher baseline levels of potassium or in those with conditions that predispose them to hyperkalemia , such as renal failure, burn injuries , or neuromuscular disorders . It's important to monitor potassium levels after administration , especially in patients at risk for hyperkalemia.
  • • increases plasma potassium levels
  • • about 0.5 mEq/L
  • • increase
  • • usually clinically insignificant
  • • healthy patients
  • • dangerous
  • • patients
  • • higher baseline levels
  • • potassium
  • • predispose them to hyperkalemia
  • • renal failure, burn injuries
  • • neuromuscular disorders
  • • important
  • • monitor potassium levels after administration
  • • patients at risk for hyperkalemia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Use of succinylcholine increases plasma K+ level by 0.5 mEq/L .
  • ➤ Use of succinylcholine increases plasma K+ level by 0.5 mEq/L .
  • ➤ Ref : Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 962-964
  • ➤ Ref :

questions.text: While giving non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockade which nerve is commonly used for monitoring the intensity of the blockade?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ulnar Nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Posterior Tibial Nerve : While this nerve can be used for monitoring , it is less commonly chosen because of its location and the bulkier muscles it innervates , which might not be as accessible during many surgical procedures.
  • • Option A
  • • Posterior Tibial Nerve
  • • monitoring
  • • less commonly chosen
  • • location
  • • bulkier muscles
  • • innervates
  • • not
  • • accessible
  • • Option C . Radial Nerve : Less commonly used for standard monitoring, as its primary innervated muscles in the arm and back of the hand are not as responsive for assessing subtle degrees of neuromuscular blockade compared to the muscles innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • • Option C
  • • Radial Nerve
  • • Less commonly used
  • • primary innervated muscles
  • • arm and back
  • • hand
  • • Option D . Facial Nerve : Although the facial nerve can be used , especially during head and neck surgeries , it's less common for general procedures . The facial expressions caused by its stimulation can be more subjective and less quantifiable compared to the hand's muscle responses to ulnar nerve stimulation.
  • • Option D
  • • Facial Nerve
  • • facial nerve can be used
  • • during head and neck surgeries
  • • less common for general procedures
  • • facial expressions
  • • stimulation
  • • more subjective
  • • less quantifiable

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade
  • ➤ Ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade
  • ➤ Ref : Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 1610
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 1610

questions.text: Administration of a small dose of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent a few minutes before succinylcholine to minimize the complications of succinylcholine is called as?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Precurarization

questions.text: Desensitization of Acetylcholine receptors after giving a large dose or continuous bolus doses of succinylcholine, resulting in prolonged neuromuscular blockade is called as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Phase II Block

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Succinylcholine, also known as suxamethonium , is a depolarizing muscle relaxant that can produce two types of neuromuscular blocks, Phase I and Phase II , which has distinct characteristics:
  • • suxamethonium
  • • depolarizing muscle relaxant
  • • two types
  • • Phase I and Phase II
  • • Phase I Block:
  • • Phase I Block:
  • • Rapid Onset : Succinylcholine acts quickly , causing depolarization of the muscle endplate shortly after administration . Persistent Depolarization : It continuously stimulates the nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction , causing persistent depolarization and resulting in muscle paralysis . Depolarization Block Features : This includes sustained muscle fasciculations followed by flaccid paralysis . Anticholinesterase Resistance : The block cannot be reversed by anticholinesterase drugs like neostigmine because these drugs increase the amount of acetylcholine , which is ineffective once the receptor is depolarized and desensitized .
  • • Rapid Onset : Succinylcholine acts quickly , causing depolarization of the muscle endplate shortly after administration .
  • • Rapid Onset
  • • quickly
  • • depolarization
  • • muscle endplate
  • • shortly after administration
  • • Persistent Depolarization : It continuously stimulates the nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction , causing persistent depolarization and resulting in muscle paralysis .
  • • Persistent Depolarization
  • • continuously
  • • nicotinic receptors
  • • neuromuscular junction
  • • persistent depolarization
  • • resulting
  • • muscle paralysis
  • • Depolarization Block Features : This includes sustained muscle fasciculations followed by flaccid paralysis .
  • • Depolarization Block Features
  • • sustained muscle fasciculations
  • • flaccid paralysis
  • • Anticholinesterase Resistance : The block cannot be reversed by anticholinesterase drugs like neostigmine because these drugs increase the amount of acetylcholine , which is ineffective once the receptor is depolarized and desensitized .
  • • Anticholinesterase Resistance
  • • cannot
  • • reversed by anticholinesterase drugs
  • • increase the amount of acetylcholine
  • • ineffective
  • • receptor is depolarized and desensitized
  • • Phase II Block (Dual Block):
  • • Phase II Block (Dual Block):
  • • Slow Onset : With prolonged exposure to succinylcholine or after repeated doses , the receptor becomes desensitized , leading to a slower onset of blockade . Desensitization of Receptors : The acetylcholine receptors become unresponsive to acetylcholine , which is similar to the mechanism seen with non-depolarizing (competitive) blockers . Similarity to Non-Depolarizing Block : The characteristics of Phase II block are akin to those produced by competitive blockers , and the block can be partially reversed by anticholinesterase drugs . Conditions for Occurrence : Phase II block is more likely to be seen when large doses of succinylcholine are used, with the administration of certain anesthetics like fluorinated anesthetics , or in patients with atypical or deficient pseudocholinesterase , which slows the breakdown of succinylcholine .
  • • Slow Onset : With prolonged exposure to succinylcholine or after repeated doses , the receptor becomes desensitized , leading to a slower onset of blockade .
  • • Slow Onset
  • • prolonged exposure
  • • succinylcholine
  • • after repeated doses
  • • becomes desensitized
  • • slower onset of blockade
  • • Desensitization of Receptors : The acetylcholine receptors become unresponsive to acetylcholine , which is similar to the mechanism seen with non-depolarizing (competitive) blockers .
  • • Desensitization of Receptors
  • • acetylcholine receptors
  • • unresponsive
  • • acetylcholine
  • • mechanism
  • • non-depolarizing (competitive) blockers
  • • Similarity to Non-Depolarizing Block : The characteristics of Phase II block are akin to those produced by competitive blockers , and the block can be partially reversed by anticholinesterase drugs .
  • • Similarity to Non-Depolarizing Block
  • • produced by competitive blockers
  • • block
  • • partially reversed
  • • anticholinesterase drugs
  • • Conditions for Occurrence : Phase II block is more likely to be seen when large doses of succinylcholine are used, with the administration of certain anesthetics like fluorinated anesthetics , or in patients with atypical or deficient pseudocholinesterase , which slows the breakdown of succinylcholine .
  • • Conditions for Occurrence
  • • seen
  • • large doses
  • • administration
  • • fluorinated anesthetics
  • • atypical
  • • deficient pseudocholinesterase
  • • slows the breakdown of succinylcholine
  • • Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical Anesthesiology 5 th edition pg 210
  • • Ref :
  • • Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical Anesthesiology 5 th edition pg 210

questions.text: What is the site of action of Rocuronium?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Neuro-Muscular Junction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Cerebellum: The cerebellum is involved in coordination of movement . Rocuronium does not act here.
  • • Option A
  • • Cerebellum:
  • • coordination of movement
  • • does not act
  • • Option B . Reticular Formation : This is a network in the brainstem involved in consciousness and arousal . Rocuronium does not act here.
  • • Option B
  • • Reticular Formation
  • • network
  • • brainstem
  • • consciousness and arousal
  • • does not act
  • • Option C . Motor Neuron : While motor neurons are involved in transmitting signals from the nervous system to muscles , rocuronium specifically acts at the synapse where motor neurons meet muscle cells , not on the motor neuron itself.
  • • Option C
  • • Motor Neuron
  • • transmitting signals
  • • nervous system to muscles
  • • synapse
  • • motor neurons
  • • meet muscle cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Rocuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that acts on the nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction , preventing muscle contraction by competing with acetylcholine for receptor sites .
  • ➤ non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker
  • ➤ nicotinic receptors
  • ➤ neuromuscular junction
  • ➤ muscle contraction
  • ➤ acetylcholine for receptor sites
  • ➤ Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 372-373
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 372-373

questions.text: Malignant hyperthermia is caused by all of the following except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Dantrolene

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a rare but life-threatening condition often triggered by certain general anesthetic agents .
  • • rare but life-threatening condition
  • • triggered
  • • certain general anesthetic agents
  • • Option A . Succinylcholine : This depolarizing muscle relaxant is a known trigger for malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals due to its action on the ryanodine receptor in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle cells.
  • • Option A
  • • Succinylcholine
  • • depolarizing muscle relaxant
  • • known trigger
  • • susceptible individuals
  • • action on the ryanodine receptor
  • • sarcoplasmic reticulum
  • • Option C . Halothane : An inhalational anesthetic that is a well-documented trigger for malignant hyperthermia due to its effect on calcium channels in muscle cells .
  • • Option C
  • • Halothane
  • • inhalational anesthetic
  • • trigger
  • • effect on calcium channels
  • • muscle cells
  • • Option D. Methoxyflurane : Another inhalational anesthetic that can trigger malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals .
  • • Option D.
  • • Methoxyflurane
  • • inhalational anesthetic
  • • trigger
  • • susceptible individuals

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Dantrolene is used to treat malignant hyperthermia and is not a trigger for the condition, unlike succinylcholine, halothane, and methoxyflurane, which can all precipitate this pharmacogenetic crisis.
  • ➤ treat malignant hyperthermia
  • ➤ not a trigger
  • ➤ MALIGNANT HYPERTHERMIA
  • ➤ MALIGNANT HYPERTHERMIA
  • ➤ It is a medical emergency characterized by raised body temperature , altered mental status and rigidity .
  • ➤ medical emergency
  • ➤ raised body temperature
  • ➤ altered mental status
  • ➤ rigidity
  • ➤ Mutation - RyR/DHPR Gene Mutation Ion responsible - Calcium Most sensitive/earliest symptom - Masseter Spasm Earliest finding - Sudden increase in EtCO 2 (>45 mmHg) Late - Fever Drugs causing Malignant Hyperthermia- Lignocaine Succinylcholine Inhalational Anesthetic Agents - Halothane, Isoflurane, Desflurane, Sevoflurane, Methoxyflurane TCA, MAO inhibitors Drug of choice - Dantrolene Sodium

  • ➤ Mutation
  • ➤ RyR/DHPR Gene Mutation

  • ➤ Most sensitive/earliest symptom

  • ➤ Earliest finding

questions.text: Which of the following statements about depolarizing neuromuscular blockade produced by succinylcholine is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Post Tetanic Facilitation and Fade Absent

options.label: B
options.text: Train of Four Ratio > 0.4 but no Fade

options.label: D
options.text: Fasciculation & Block potentiated by Volatile Anaesthetic Agents

questions.correct_answer: C. Block is Reversed by Neostigmine
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Block is Reversed by Neostigmine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Depolarizing neuromuscular blockade produced by succinylcholine has unique characteristics :
  • • Depolarizing neuromuscular blockade
  • • succinylcholine
  • • unique characteristics
  • • Option A . Post-Tetanic Facilitation and Fade Absent : In depolarizing blockade, post-tetanic potentiation or facilitation and fade are typically absent because the mechanism of blockade is persistent depolarization , not receptor competition or presynaptic inhibition of acetylcholine release.
  • • Option A
  • • Post-Tetanic Facilitation and Fade Absent
  • • typically absent
  • • mechanism of blockade
  • • persistent depolarization
  • • Option B . Train of Four Ratio > 0.4 but No Fade : With succinylcholine-induced depolarizing blockade, the train of four (TOF) ratio can be greater than 0.4 without fade because the block is characterized by a persistent depolarization of the neuromuscular endplate , not an interference with acetylcholine binding as seen with non-depolarizing blockers.
  • • Option B
  • • Train of Four Ratio > 0.4 but No Fade
  • • block
  • • persistent depolarization
  • • neuromuscular endplate
  • • Option D . Fasciculation & Block Potentiated by Volatile Anesthetic Agents : Volatile anesthetics are known to potentiate the effects of succinylcholine , leading to more pronounced fasciculations and a deeper neuromuscular block .
  • • Option D
  • • Fasciculation & Block Potentiated by Volatile Anesthetic Agents
  • • potentiate
  • • effects of succinylcholine
  • • pronounced fasciculations
  • • deeper neuromuscular block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: A 40-year-old female was given fentanyl, propofol and pancuronium for induction of anesthesia. After extubation she was observed to have limited movement of the upper body and chest wall in the recovery room. She was conscious and alert, but voluntary respiratory effort was limited. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Incomplete Reversal of Pancuronium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical scenario describes a situation where the patient is conscious and alert but has limited voluntary movement , particularly in the upper body and respiratory effort , after anesthesia.
  • • conscious
  • • alert
  • • limited voluntary movement
  • • upper body
  • • respiratory effort
  • • Let’s evaluate each option:
  • • Let’s evaluate each option:
  • • Option B . Pulmonary Embolism : While it can lead to respiratory distress , the patient would likely exhibit signs of acute distress , hypoxia , and hemodynamic instability , not alertness with isolated respiratory effort limitation .
  • • Option B
  • • Pulmonary Embolism
  • • lead to respiratory distress
  • • exhibit signs
  • • acute distress
  • • hypoxia
  • • hemodynamic instability
  • • not alertness with isolated respiratory effort limitation
  • • Option C . Fentanyl Induced Chest Wall Rigidity : High doses of fentanyl can cause chest wall rigidity , making ventilation difficult . However, this typically occurs during or immediately after rapid intravenous administration , not during the recovery period.
  • • Option C
  • • Fentanyl Induced Chest Wall Rigidity
  • • High doses
  • • fentanyl
  • • cause chest wall rigidity
  • • making ventilation difficult
  • • typically
  • • during or immediately
  • • rapid intravenous administration
  • • Option D . Diffusion Hypoxia : This occurs after the discontinuation of nitrous oxide anesthesia when there is a rapid diffusion of nitrous oxide out of the blood into the lungs , diluting the oxygen and leading to transient hypoxia . It would not typically cause limited movement as described.
  • • Option D
  • • Diffusion Hypoxia
  • • discontinuation of nitrous oxide anesthesia
  • • rapid diffusion
  • • nitrous oxide
  • • out
  • • blood into the lungs
  • • diluting the oxygen
  • • leading to transient hypoxia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The most likely diagnosis when a patient is alert with limited upper body and chest wall movement after anesthesia is incomplete reversal of pancuronium , a long-acting non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker , which can result in residual paralysis affecting voluntary muscle movements , including respiration.
  • ➤ alert with limited upper body
  • ➤ chest wall movement
  • ➤ incomplete reversal of pancuronium
  • ➤ long-acting non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker
  • ➤ result in residual paralysis
  • ➤ affecting voluntary muscle movements
  • ➤ Ref : Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 1610
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Millers Anesthesia 8 th edition pg 1610

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes Hoffman elimination?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Atracurium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Atracurium Pharmacokinetics:
  • • Atracurium Pharmacokinetics:
  • • Dose: 0.5 mg/kg Onset of action : 2–3 minutes ; Duration of action : 10–15 minutes
  • • Dose: 0.5 mg/kg
  • • Dose: 0.5 mg/kg
  • • Onset of action : 2–3 minutes ;
  • • Onset of action
  • • 2–3 minutes
  • • Duration of action : 10–15 minutes
  • • Duration of action
  • • 10–15 minutes
  • • Metabolism
  • • Metabolism
  • • It undergoes spontaneous degradation in plasma through Hoffman degradation , which is independent of hepatic & renal functions .
  • • It undergoes spontaneous degradation in plasma through Hoffman degradation , which is independent of hepatic & renal functions .
  • • undergoes
  • • spontaneous degradation
  • • through Hoffman degradation
  • • independent
  • • hepatic & renal functions
  • • Systemic Effects
  • • Systemic Effects
  • • Histamine release causes flushing , hypotension , and bronchospasm . CNS : At higher doses , it is metabolized to laudanosine , which can cross blood brain barrier & produce convulsions . Allergic reactions can occur. It is the muscle relaxant of choice in the following groups of patients because its metabolism is independent of renal and liver functions . Hepatic failure Renal failure If reversal agent is contraindicated, e.g., Myasthenia gravis New-borns Old age
  • • Histamine release causes flushing , hypotension , and bronchospasm .
  • • Histamine
  • • flushing
  • • hypotension
  • • bronchospasm
  • • CNS : At higher doses , it is metabolized to laudanosine , which can cross blood brain barrier & produce convulsions .
  • • CNS
  • • higher doses
  • • metabolized
  • • laudanosine
  • • cross blood brain barrier
  • • produce convulsions
  • • Allergic reactions can occur.
  • • Allergic reactions
  • • It is the muscle relaxant of choice in the following groups of patients because its metabolism is independent of renal and liver functions . Hepatic failure Renal failure If reversal agent is contraindicated, e.g., Myasthenia gravis New-borns Old age
  • • muscle relaxant of choice
  • • metabolism is independent of renal and liver functions
  • • Hepatic failure Renal failure If reversal agent is contraindicated, e.g., Myasthenia gravis New-borns Old age
  • • Hepatic failure
  • • Renal failure
  • • If reversal agent is contraindicated, e.g., Myasthenia gravis
  • • New-borns
  • • Old age
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Atracurium is metabolized by Hoffman elimination , an organ-independent process , making it suitable for use in patients with hepatic or renal failure , as well as in myasthenia gravis , neonates , and the elderly . It has an onset of 2-3 minutes , a short duration of action , but can cause histamine release and, at high doses , produce CNS effects due to laudanosine .
  • • metabolized by Hoffman elimination
  • • organ-independent process
  • • making
  • • suitable for use
  • • hepatic or renal failure
  • • myasthenia gravis
  • • neonates
  • • elderly
  • • onset of 2-3 minutes
  • • short duration of action
  • • histamine release
  • • high doses
  • • CNS effects due to laudanosine
  • • Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 394
  • • Ref :
  • • Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 394

questions.text: Most common drug causing allergy in immediate perioperative period is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Antibiotics > Muscle relaxants

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Antibiotics are now the most common cause of anaphylaxis in immediate peri-operative period.
  • • Antibiotics are now the most common cause of anaphylaxis in immediate peri-operative period.
  • • Antibiotics > Muscle relaxants are most common cause of anaphylaxis during anesthesia. Among muscle relaxants, Succinylcholine induces mast cell degranulation by crosslinking IgE receptors on mast cells . Succinylcholine is more likely to cause anaphylaxis than nondepolarizing muscle relaxants . Anaphylaxis may develop even on the first exposure to a muscle relaxant since they may already be sensitized to quaternary ammonium compounds present in products of daily use . Neostigmine & Morphine also can cause anaphylaxis .
  • • Antibiotics > Muscle relaxants are most common cause of anaphylaxis during anesthesia.
  • • most common cause
  • • anaphylaxis
  • • Among muscle relaxants, Succinylcholine induces mast cell degranulation by crosslinking IgE receptors on mast cells .
  • • Succinylcholine induces
  • • mast cell degranulation
  • • crosslinking IgE receptors
  • • mast cells
  • • Succinylcholine is more likely to cause anaphylaxis than nondepolarizing muscle relaxants .
  • • cause anaphylaxis
  • • nondepolarizing muscle relaxants
  • • Anaphylaxis may develop even on the first exposure to a muscle relaxant since they may already be sensitized to quaternary ammonium compounds present in products of daily use .
  • • develop
  • • first exposure
  • • muscle relaxant
  • • already
  • • sensitized
  • • quaternary ammonium compounds
  • • products of daily use
  • • Neostigmine & Morphine also can cause anaphylaxis .
  • • Neostigmine & Morphine
  • • anaphylaxis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Antibiotics, particularly beta-lactams , are the most common cause of immediate perioperative anaphylaxis , followed by neuromuscular blockers due to the presence of ammonium ions which are allergenic .
  • ➤ beta-lactams
  • ➤ most common cause
  • ➤ immediate perioperative anaphylaxis
  • ➤ neuromuscular blockers
  • ➤ presence of ammonium ions
  • ➤ allergenic
  • ➤ Antibiotics>Neuromuscular Blockers> Chlorhexidine>Local Anaesthetic> Latex
  • ➤ Antibiotics>Neuromuscular Blockers> Chlorhexidine>Local Anaesthetic> Latex
  • ➤ Ref : https://resources.wfsahq.org/atotw/an-update-on-perioperative anaphylaxis/#:~:text=Risk%20factors%20for%20anaphylaxis%20include,lactam%20antibiotics)%2C%20and%20latex .
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ https://resources.wfsahq.org/atotw/an-update-on-perioperative anaphylaxis/#:~:text=Risk%20factors%20for%20anaphylaxis%20include,lactam%20antibiotics)%2C%20and%20latex
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Shortest acting non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mivacurium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Muscle Relaxants
  • • Muscle Relaxants
  • • Mivacurium is the only non-depolarizing blocker that is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase and is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant .
  • • only non-depolarizing blocker
  • • metabolized
  • • plasma cholinesterase
  • • shortest-acting muscle relaxant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Long Acting: Pancuronium, Pipecuronium
  • ➤ Intermediate Acting: Atracurium,Cisatracurium.Vecuronium,Rocuronium
  • ➤ Short acting: Mivacurium Ultra-short acting: Gantacurium
  • ➤ Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 366-406
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 366-406

questions.text: Choose the Correct Answer: Assertion: Atracurium can be safely given in renal failure patients Reason: Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement.

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker which can be safely administered to patients with renal failure due to its unique metabolism , which includes Hofmann elimination .
  • • non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker
  • • safely administered
  • • patients with renal failure
  • • unique metabolism
  • • includes Hofmann elimination
  • • Assertion : "Atracurium can be safely given in renal failure patients" is a true statement . Since atracurium is metabolized via Hofmann elimination , it does not rely on renal or hepatic pathways for its clearance , making it a safe choice for patients with renal impairment . Reason : "Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination" is also a true statement . Hofmann elimination is a chemical process that occurs at physiological pH and temperature , resulting in the drug's breakdown independently of organ function .
  • • Assertion : "Atracurium can be safely given in renal failure patients" is a true statement . Since atracurium is metabolized via Hofmann elimination , it does not rely on renal or hepatic pathways for its clearance , making it a safe choice for patients with renal impairment .
  • • Assertion
  • • true statement
  • • metabolized via Hofmann elimination
  • • does not rely
  • • renal or hepatic pathways
  • • clearance
  • • safe choice
  • • patients
  • • renal impairment
  • • Reason : "Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination" is also a true statement . Hofmann elimination is a chemical process that occurs at physiological pH and temperature , resulting in the drug's breakdown independently of organ function .
  • • Reason
  • • true statement
  • • Hofmann elimination
  • • chemical process
  • • physiological pH
  • • temperature
  • • drug's breakdown
  • • independently
  • • organ function
  • • Thus, the reason "Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination" is indeed the correct explanation for why atracurium can be safely administered in renal failure patients .
  • • correct explanation
  • • safely administered
  • • renal failure patients

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Atracurium is suitable for use in patients with renal failure because it undergoes Hofmann elimination , a non-enzymatic process that allows for the drug's clearance without relying on kidney function .
  • ➤ suitable
  • ➤ patients with renal failure
  • ➤ undergoes Hofmann elimination
  • ➤ non-enzymatic process
  • ➤ allows
  • ➤ drug's clearance
  • ➤ without relying
  • ➤ kidney function
  • ➤ Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 394-396
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 394-396

questions.text: All are characteristics of Non depolarizing Neuromuscular Blocking agents except?

options.label: A
options.text: Fade on Train of Four Stimulation

options.label: B
options.text: Tetanic Stimulation is Followed by Post Tetanic Facilitation.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Shows fasciculation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fasciculations are seen with depolarizing neuromuscular blocker since they have agonistic effect on nicotinic cholinergic receptor.
  • • Fasciculations
  • • depolarizing neuromuscular blocker
  • • agonistic effect
  • • nicotinic cholinergic receptor.
  • • Let’s evaluate other options:
  • • Option A . Fade on Train of Four Stimulation : Non-depolarizing agents show a characteristic fade on repetitive nerve stimulation like train-of-four (TOF) , which is not present with depolarizing agents in a phase I block .
  • • Option A
  • • Fade on Train of Four Stimulation
  • • Non-depolarizing agents
  • • characteristic fade
  • • repetitive nerve stimulation
  • • train-of-four (TOF)
  • • not present
  • • depolarizing agents
  • • phase I block
  • • Option B . Tetanic Stimulation is Followed by Post Tetanic Facilitation : After tetanic stimulation, there is an increased response to subsequent twitches , known as post-tetanic potentiation , which is seen with non-depolarizing blocks due to increased acetylcholine release .
  • • Option B
  • • Tetanic Stimulation is Followed by Post Tetanic Facilitation
  • • increased response
  • • subsequent twitches
  • • post-tetanic potentiation
  • • non-depolarizing blocks
  • • increased acetylcholine release
  • • Option D . Reversed by Neostigmine : Non-depolarizing blocks can be reversed by anticholinesterase drugs like neostigmine, which increase acetylcholine levels in the synaptic cleft , outcompeting the blocker for the receptor .
  • • Option D
  • • Reversed by Neostigmine
  • • Non-depolarizing blocks
  • • reversed
  • • anticholinesterase drugs
  • • increase acetylcholine levels
  • • synaptic cleft
  • • outcompeting the blocker
  • • receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Fasciculation is a feature of depolarizing neuromuscular blockers due to their agonistic effect on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and is not characteristic of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents, which are marked by fade on TOF stimulation and can be reversed by neostigmine .
  • ➤ depolarizing neuromuscular blockers
  • ➤ agonistic effect
  • ➤ nicotinic acetylcholine receptors
  • ➤ not characteristic
  • ➤ marked by fade
  • ➤ TOF stimulation
  • ➤ reversed by neostigmine
  • ➤ A phase I depolarization block from succinylcholine does not exhibit fade during tetanus or train-of-four; neither does it demonstrate post tetanic potentiation.
  • ➤ A phase I depolarization block from succinylcholine does not exhibit fade during tetanus or train-of-four; neither does it demonstrate post tetanic potentiation.
  • ➤ Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 378
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 378

questions.text: Metabolite of which muscle relaxant can cause seizures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Atracurium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Laudanosine is a breakdown product of atracurium's Hofmann elimination which can cause seizures when accumulated . This is seen when atracurium is given in large doses or in hepatic/renal failure .
  • • Laudanosine
  • • breakdown product
  • • atracurium's Hofmann elimination
  • • cause seizures when accumulated
  • • atracurium
  • • large doses
  • • hepatic/renal failure
  • • Cisatracurium is a stereoisomer of atracurium , which produces lesser laudanosine than atracurium.
  • • stereoisomer
  • • atracurium
  • • produces lesser laudanosine
  • • Educational objective
  • • Educational objective
  • • Laudanosine is a breakdown product of atracurium's Hofmann elimination which can cause seizures when accumulated. This is seen when atracurium is given in large doses or in hepatic/ renal failure.
  • • Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 394
  • • Ref :
  • • Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 394

questions.text: Which of these non-depolarizing agents is a Benzylisoquinoline compound?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Atracurium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 388
  • • Ref :
  • • Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7 th edition pg 388

questions.text: Which of these is the most cardio stable muscle relaxant?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Vecuronium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Pancuronium : This non-depolarizing muscle relaxant can increase heart rate and blood pressure due to vagolytic effects ( inhibition of vagus nerve activity ), making it less cardio-stable .
  • • Option A
  • • Pancuronium
  • • non-depolarizing muscle relaxant
  • • increase heart rate
  • • blood pressure
  • • vagolytic effects
  • • inhibition of vagus nerve activity
  • • less cardio-stable
  • • Option B . Atracurium : While atracurium is a good choice for patients with renal or hepatic impairment due to Hoffman elimination , it can cause histamine release , which may lead to hypotension and tachycardia .
  • • Option B
  • • Atracurium
  • • good choice for patients
  • • renal or hepatic impairment
  • • Hoffman elimination
  • • histamine release
  • • lead to hypotension
  • • tachycardia
  • • Option D . Rocuronium : Rocuronium is similar to vecuronium in terms of cardiovascular stability , but it has a rapid onset of action . However, in higher doses , it may have slight vagolytic activity .
  • • Option D
  • • Rocuronium
  • • similar to vecuronium
  • • cardiovascular stability
  • • rapid onset of action
  • • higher doses
  • • may
  • • slight vagolytic activity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Vecuronium is considered the most cardio-stable muscle relaxant because it lacks the vagolytic activity of pancuronium and the histamine-releasing potential of atracurium , leading to fewer cardiovascular side effects .
  • ➤ most cardio-stable muscle relaxant
  • ➤ lacks the vagolytic activity of pancuronium
  • ➤ histamine-releasing potential
  • ➤ atracurium
  • ➤ leading to fewer cardiovascular side effects
  • ➤ Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 7 th edition pg 40
  • ➤ Ref : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 7 th edition pg 40

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma is undergoing liver resection surgery. Ideal muscle relaxant for this case would be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Atracurium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a patient with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma undergoing liver resection , the metabolism and clearance of drugs can be significantly impaired . The choice of muscle relaxant in such cases is crucial .
  • • cirrhosis
  • • hepatocellular carcinoma
  • • liver resection
  • • metabolism
  • • clearance of drugs
  • • significantly impaired
  • • choice of muscle
  • • relaxant
  • • crucial
  • • Atracurium and Cisatracurium undergo Hofmann elimination and thus are not dependent on liver function for their clearance.
  • • Atracurium
  • • Cisatracurium
  • • Hofmann elimination
  • • not dependent
  • • liver function
  • • clearance.
  • • Option A . Pancuronium : This muscle relaxant is largely eliminated by the kidneys , but it is also metabolized by the liver . In patients with liver impairment , its effects could be prolonged and unpredictable .
  • • Option A
  • • Pancuronium
  • • muscle relaxant
  • • largely eliminated
  • • kidneys
  • • metabolized by the liver
  • • liver impairment
  • • effects
  • • prolonged
  • • unpredictable
  • • Option C . Vecuronium : Vecuronium is primarily metabolized in the liver , and its clearance could be reduced in patients with liver dysfunction , leading to prolonged effects .
  • • Option C
  • • Vecuronium
  • • primarily metabolized
  • • liver
  • • clearance
  • • reduced in patients
  • • liver dysfunction
  • • leading to prolonged effects
  • • Option D . Rocuronium : Similar to vecuronium, rocuronium is also metabolized in the liver to a significant extent, and its use in liver impairment could result in prolonged neuromuscular blockade .
  • • Option D
  • • Rocuronium
  • • also metabolized in the liver
  • • use in liver impairment
  • • prolonged neuromuscular blockade

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atracurium is the preferred muscle relaxant for patients with liver dysfunction , such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, due to its Hofmann elimination which is independent of liver function .
  • ➤ preferred muscle relaxant
  • ➤ patients with liver dysfunction
  • ➤ Hofmann elimination
  • ➤ independent of liver function
